fields.headline: The conflict in numbers
fields.bodyText: Who fled and who returned · The vast majority of Iraq's population of more than 27 million people are muslim. · Society is divided along ethnic (Arabs and Kurds) and religious lines (Shia and Sunni) while the country is also home to small Christian, Turkoman and other minorities. · Under the rule of Saddam Hussein, political life was dominated by Sunni Arabs. · Post-invasion elections in Iraq have been marked by high turnouts on the part of Shias, whose leaders have gained power. Many Sunnis have refused to engage in the political process but their vote grew during elections in December 2005. · Following months of political deadlock, Nouri Maliki, a Shia politician, was invited to form a government in April 2006 by President Jalal Talabani, a Kurd. · The Kurds live mainly in the north, where they have dropped claims for full independence, settling instead for a federal Iraq. · An estimated 2.2 million Iraqis have fled the country since the invasion in 2003 and more than one million are thought to have been internally displaced. · Tens of thousands of internally displaced people have voluntarily returned to their homes in recent months.
